greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest prime of form (2n+1)*2^m-1 for some m, or 0 if no such prime exists.
comment: If a(329) > 0 it is greater than 659*2^10000. - _Robert Israel_, Jul 01 2014
Indeed, a(329) > 659*2^100000 if it is nonzero. There does not appear to be a covering set, though, so probably a(329) > 0. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Jul 02 2014
a(329) = 659*2^800516 - 1 (found by David W Linton in 2004). - _Robert Israel_, Jul 04 2014
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..328
Index entries for sequences of n such that k*2^n-1 (or k*2^n+1) is prime
example: a(5)=43 because 2*5+1=11 and smallest prime of the form 11*2^m-1 is 43 (since 10 and 21 are not prime)
maple: while not isprime(t) do t:= 2*t+1 od;
results.author: _Henry Bottomley_, Jul 24 2000
